chapters.summary: Data wrapper changed their model from being free to paying. A lot of small kind of independent newspapers are using that still for their web based graphics. It feels like it's got through that kind of infancy stage and has found its place.
chapters.gist: Data Wrapper and the Free Press
chapters.headline: Some startups have changed their model from being free to paying for content

chapters.summary: Another interesting tool is shiny by RSTudio, which is based on D3. You can directly code something that goes on to the web and there is interaction on top of it. I think it's a major step towards making R something that can be a little bit more interactive. Rise of the data scientists.
chapters.gist: What are the latest data visualization tools in R?
chapters.headline: On the web and general data visualization scene, there are few interesting tools

chapters.summary: There's still a lack of visual thinking in statistics and in data science. Many data scientists need help from visualization experts. I'm really surprised that there's still such a big divide between the two.
chapters.gist: Top Data Scientists: More Visual Thinking in Data Science
chapters.headline: There's still a lack of visual thinking in statistics and in data science

chapters.summary: One thing that really impressed me was the serial podcast. It's sort of an investigative, a reinvestigation of a murder case that happened 15 years ago. What I found really interesting is the strong first person perspective. I would recommend listening to the podcast and thinking about what that means for other types of media.
chapters.gist: The Making of a Serial Podcast
chapters.headline: One thing that impressed me was the serial podcast about a murder case

chapters.summary: For 2015, I'd love to see more stories built around visuals and data as opposed to word. I also think we will see great stuff from like natural scientists next year. Maybe traditional journalism still is even still to word focused.
chapters.gist: Top Tech Writers' Hopes and Nightmares for 2015
chapters.headline: Twitter users share their hopes and fears for 2015

chapters.summary: There is a big, big lack of statistical literacy, data literacy, visual literacy, however you want to call it. My hope is that there will be more resources to help people learn more about not only about visualizations, but also how to deal with data in general.
chapters.gist: What's to Do About Visualization in 2015?
chapters.headline: One of the themes that I'm hoping for next year is visualization literacy

chapters.summary: And just on the broader point of visualization, literacy. We're working on a research project, and this concludes in March of this year. Will there be a report from the research project? Reports, videos, presentations, all sorts stuff. And possibly podcasts.
chapters.gist: Top Visualization Literacy Issues
chapters.headline: We're working on a research project on visualization, literacy

chapters.summary: The last tweet was from Ben Jones, who said hopes for 2015 continued high level collaboration database across disciplines and tools. So let's hope that doesn't happen. That would be really bad for databases.
chapters.gist: #2015 Hopes for a Collaboration Database
chapters.headline: Ben Jones hopes for 2015 continued high level collaboration database across disciplines

chapters.summary: My last kind of prediction for 2015 would be a big showing from the Guardian and specifically the Guardian UK. There's more academic, more interest and more attention from academia, from the academic viz side in presentation. No big revolution, just continued evolution.
chapters.gist: Predictions for 2015
chapters.headline: My last kind of prediction for 2015 would be a big showing from the Guardian
